awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Life Out of Water - Possibility of Evolution in Non-Aqueous Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Life on Earth is thought to have emerged in water phase. It is not known whether the chemical processes of Life can only occur in a polar liquid like water, or also in non-polar, oily liquids. This project will examine chemistry in non-polar phases to ask whether certain aspects of genetic coding and mutation with selection can take place in the absence of water. The project will provide training in organic chemistry, biochemistry and physical chemistry to many students. 

Water is assumed to be a necessity for life. This project will study a counter-factual proposition that certain aspects of extant life on Earth, including genetic coding and mutation with selection, can be reimplemented in the absence of water. To that end, the solubility, folding, assembly and co-assembly of non-polar homologs of canonical nucleic acid monomers and oligomers, wherein the phosphodiester linkage is substituted with a non-polar linkage will be characterized. Dynamic-covalent reactions as alternatives to base-pairing in organic media will be explored and in vitro selection will be performed in oil phase and in oil-water alternating regimes. The project will involve undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, with student exchange between laboratories, and facilitate mentoring and outreach through SAGANet and K-12 workshops.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored interactions between traditional biomolecules and oil phases. We explored the partitioning of nucleic acids, amino acids, and their polymers into non-aqueous solvents. The portioning was driven by thermodynamics, however both proteins and nucleic acid polymers were difficult to predict. The project also worked on exploring the effects of oil on chemical evolution during wet-dry cycling of a synthetic prebiotic soup. When oil was added to the chemical mixture, the products of wet-dry cycling were statistically distinct from the samples without oil added. This indicates that oil phases should be included in studies on the origins of life, as they were likely present on early Earth, and are present on other solar bodies (e.g., Titan). We also observed decyl alanine esters in our wet-dry cycling experiments, leading to the finding that oily alcohols can react with amino acids to generate membrane-forming amphiphiles. Additionally, while some of the amino acid products formed membranes under the conditions tested, others did not depending on the amino acid identity. This indicates that selection may be possible for this amphiphile type, which could be used to drive early evolutionary processes. All of the work carried out in this project was completed with the help of undergraduate students, who were involved in method development, sample preparation and analysis, data analysis, and writing papers. Some of the students presented at conferences, and many have gone on to pursue PhDs. Their work was instrumental in the progress that was made throughout this project.
